title: Should you trust unanimous decisions? - Derek Abbott

multiple-choice.question: What is the paradox of unanimity?

options.text: Because it suggests a systemic error or bias.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is statistically unlikely.

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: Because it indicates a lack of variability.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it suggests a systemic error or bias.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is statistically likely.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is less susceptible to errors.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: That a unanimous decision is always the most reliable.

options.label: B
options.text: That a majority vote is always the best way to make a decision.

options.label: C
options.text: That a unanimous decision can be less reliable due to potential systemic errors or biases.

options.label: D
options.text: That a unanimous decision is only reliable in situations with low uncertainty.

multiple-choice.question: How might the paradox of unanimity apply to real-world situations?

options.label: B
options.text: It only applies to presidential elections.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the paradox of unanimity?

options.label: A
options.text: That a unanimous decision is always the most reliable.

options.text: That a majority vote is always the best way to make a decision.

options.label: C
